milestone: Cries to express needs (hunger, discomfort, sleepiness)
activities: Respond promptly to cries to build trust and communication.
Notice different cry patterns.
Soothe with a calm voice and gentle touch.

milestone: Exhibits Rooting, Sucking, and Swallowing reflexes
activities: Gently stroke their cheek to elicit the rooting reflex.
Ensure a calm feeding environment.
Allow non-nutritive sucking on a pacifier or clean finger for self-soothing.

milestone: Displays Moro (startle) reflex to loud noise or sudden movement
activities: Swaddle your baby to help them feel secure and manage the startle reflex.
Use a calm voice to soothe them after a startle.
Avoid abrupt, loud noises when possible.

milestone: Grasps a finger when placed in palm (Palmar Grasp Reflex)
activities: Gently place your clean finger or a soft, thin rattle in their palm to encourage this reflex.
Stroke the back of their hand to encourage them to open it.

milestone: Recognizes caregiver's scent and voice
activities: Hold your baby skin-to-skin.
Talk and sing to them frequently in a soothing tone.
Maintain consistency in who provides care.

milestone: Lifts head briefly during tummy time
activities: Start with very short, supervised tummy time sessions (1-2 minutes) multiple times a day on your chest or a firm surface.

milestone: Focuses on objects 8-12 inches away (distance to your face)
activities: Hold high-contrast (black and white) cards or your face at this distance.
Talk to them while making eye contact to encourage focus.

milestone: Turns head toward light sources
activities: Place a soft, dim lamp to the side of their bassinet.
Notice how they turn towards a window with natural light.

milestone: Makes eye contact, especially during feeding
activities: Hold your baby close during feedings.
Gaze into their eyes and smile gently.
Minimize distractions during this bonding time.

milestone: Begins to follow a slow-moving object to midline
activities: Slowly move a high-contrast toy or your face from one side toward the center of their vision.

milestone: Moves head from side to side when lying on stomach
activities: During tummy time, make sounds or place toys slightly to one side to encourage them to turn their head.

milestone: Begins to make cooing sounds (vowel sounds like 'ooh' and 'aah')
activities: Talk to your baby and pause, giving them a chance to 'reply'.
Imitate their cooing sounds to encourage a 'conversation'.

milestone: Social smile emerges (smiles in response to you)
activities: Smile at your baby often, especially when they are calm and alert.
Use an expressive, happy tone of voice.

milestone: Tracks objects past midline (follows from one side to the other)
activities: Slowly move a colorful toy (red is one of the first colors they see well) in an arc in front of their face.

milestone: Holds head up at a 45-degree angle during tummy time
activities: Increase tummy time duration as they get stronger.
Place a baby-safe mirror in front of them to motivate them to lift their head.

milestone: Hands are more frequently open, less often in a fist
activities: Gently massage their palms and stroke the back of their hands.
Offer toys with different textures for them to touch.

milestone: Recognizes familiar faces at a close distance
activities: Spend lots of face-to-face time with your baby.
Play simple games like peeking around a blanket.

milestone: Gurgles and makes other throaty sounds
activities: Respond to their sounds with enthusiasm.
Narrate your day to them, describing what you are doing.

milestone: Pushes up on forearms/elbows during tummy time
activities: Use a rolled towel under their chest and armpits for support during tummy time.
Place engaging toys just within their sight.

milestone: Brings hands to midline (together at their chest)
activities: Dangle a toy directly over their chest to encourage them to reach with both hands.
Gently guide their hands together to play pat-a-cake.

milestone: Laughs or chuckles
activities: Make silly faces or funny noises.
Gently tickle their tummy or blow raspberries on their belly.

milestone: Bears some weight on legs when held in a standing position
activities: Hold your baby under their arms and let their feet touch the floor or your lap.
Gently bounce them to build leg strength.

milestone: Bats at dangling objects (may not be accurate)
activities: Use a play gym with hanging toys.
Dangle a soft, colorful toy within their reach and encourage them to swipe at it.

milestone: Holds head steady without support when held upright
activities: Carry your baby in an upright position (facing out in a carrier, once they have good head control).
Sit them on your lap while you read a book.

milestone: Reaches for a toy with both hands
activities: Offer a toy that is big enough to require two hands, like a soft ball or large plush ring.

milestone: Pushes up with straight arms during tummy time
activities: Encourage them to reach for toys placed slightly further away during tummy time.

milestone: Begins to roll from tummy to back (often accidentally at first)
activities: During tummy time, if they push up high, they might roll over. Cheer them on!
Place toys to one side to encourage the weight shift that leads to a roll.

milestone: Copies some facial expressions, like smiling or frowning
activities: Get close to your baby's face and make simple, exaggerated expressions.
Wait to see if they try to imitate you.

milestone: Babbles with more consonant sounds (p, b, m)
activities: Have back-and-forth babble conversations.
Read books with rhyming sounds.

milestone: Grasps and holds a rattle or toy
activities: Offer lightweight, easy-to-grip toys like plastic links or soft rattles.

milestone: Explores objects with mouth
activities: Provide a variety of safe, clean teething toys with different textures.
Ensure small objects are kept out of reach.

milestone: Turns to locate the source of a sound
activities: Sit behind your baby and make a soft sound on one side. See if they turn their head to find it.
Use crinkle toys or soft rattles.

milestone: Recognizes their own name and may turn when called
activities: Use their name frequently in a positive, happy tone.
Call their name from a short distance to see if they respond.

milestone: Transfers an object from one hand to the other
activities: Hand them a toy and then offer a second one to encourage them to switch the first toy to their other hand to grab the new one.

milestone: Shows clear excitement when seeing caregiver
activities: Greet your baby with a big smile and enthusiastic voice when you enter the room.

milestone: Begins to sit with support (propped with pillows or hands)
activities: Prop your baby in a corner of the sofa or with pillows.
Sit them between your legs on the floor and read a book.

milestone: Makes 'raspberry' sounds (blowing bubbles)
activities: Model making raspberry sounds for them to imitate.
It's a fun game and great for oral motor development.

milestone: Begins to roll from back to tummy (requires more coordination)
activities: Place toys just out of reach to encourage them to roll towards them.
Give them plenty of supervised floor time.

milestone: Rakes at small objects with fingers
activities: Place a few baby-safe puffs or a soft, small toy on their high chair tray and let them practice moving them.

milestone: Shows curiosity about objects and tries to get things out of reach
activities: Place an exciting toy just beyond their reach to motivate them to scoot, roll, or stretch to get it.

milestone: Begins to babble in chains ('ba-ba-ba', 'da-da-da')
activities: Respond to their babbles as if they are talking.
Narrate what they might be 'saying': "Ba-ba-ba! Are you talking about the ball?"

milestone: Looks at self in a mirror and may smile or babble
activities: Provide a baby-safe mirror during tummy time or seated play.
Sit with them and point to "the baby" in the mirror.

milestone: Sits well without support
activities: Place toys in a circle around your baby to encourage them to twist and reach, building core strength and balance.

milestone: Begins to feed self finger foods (e.g., dissolvable puffs)
activities: Offer small, soft, pea-sized pieces of food on a high chair tray.
This helps develop the pincer grasp and independence.

milestone: Gets into crawling position (on hands and knees, may rock back and forth)
activities: Place toys just out of reach to motivate forward movement.
Get on the floor and crawl yourself to show them how it's done.

milestone: Shows clear preference for a primary caregiver; may show stranger anxiety
activities: Acknowledge their feelings and provide reassurance.
Don't force interaction with strangers.
Allow them to observe from the safety of your arms.

milestone: Looks for an object that is partially hidden
activities: Play a game where you hide a favorite toy under a small blanket, but leave part of it showing.
Cheer when they find it.

milestone: Bangs two objects together
activities: Give them two blocks or two toy spoons and show them how to bang them together.
This teaches cause and effect and bilateral coordination.

milestone: Responds to their name consistently
activities: Use their name often in daily conversation.
When they look at you after you call their name, reward them with a big smile.

milestone: Crawls forward (on belly or hands and knees)
activities: Create a safe, baby-proofed area for them to explore.
Place pillows for them to crawl over to build strength and coordination.

milestone: Responds to simple verbal requests, like "Come here"
activities: Use gestures along with words.
When you say "Come here," hold your arms out wide and smile.

milestone: Pulls to a standing position using furniture
activities: Ensure furniture is sturdy and anchored to the wall.
Place enticing toys on the sofa or a low table to encourage them to pull up.

milestone: Says "mama" and "dada" nonspecifically (not yet tied to parents)
activities: Repeat the sounds back to them.
Point to yourself and say "mama," and to your partner and say "dada" to help them make the connection.

milestone: Uses pincer grasp (thumb and index finger) to pick up small objects
activities: Offer puffs, small pieces of soft fruit, or cooked peas for them to practice picking up.
Supervise closely.

milestone: Finds objects that are completely hidden (demonstrates object permanence)
activities: Hide a toy under one of two or three small blankets and let them find it.
Use stacking cups to hide a small toy underneath.

milestone: Begins to understand the word "no" (may pause or stop briefly)
activities: Use "no" firmly and calmly for safety issues.
Redirect their attention immediately to an acceptable activity.

milestone: Imitates simple gestures (e.g., clapping, waving "bye-bye")
activities: Clap your hands during a song or wave "bye-bye" when someone leaves.
Gently guide their hands to help them learn the motion.

milestone: Puts objects *into* a container
activities: Provide a small bucket and blocks.
Show them how to drop the blocks in.
This is a classic and engaging activity.

milestone: Cruises by walking sideways while holding onto furniture
activities: Arrange furniture to create a safe "cruising path."
Place a toy at the end of the coffee table to motivate them to move towards it.

milestone: Shows a specific book or toy to a caregiver to initiate play
activities: Respond with enthusiasm when they bring you something.
Say, "Oh, you brought me your book! Should we read it together?"

milestone: Takes objects *out of* a container
activities: Fill a small basket or tissue box with safe items like large pom-poms or silk scarves for them to pull out.

milestone: Follows a simple one-step command without gestures (e.g., "Give me the ball")
activities: Practice with familiar objects.
Praise them heavily when they follow the instruction correctly.

milestone: Stands alone for a few seconds
activities: Sit on the floor and encourage them to let go of the furniture and come to you.
Offer them a toy that requires two hands to hold.

milestone: Drinks from a sippy cup independently
activities: Start with a cup that has a soft spout and two handles.
Model drinking from the cup yourself.

milestone: Says "mama" and "dada" with meaning (correctly identifies parents)
activities: Shower them with praise and affection when they correctly identify you.
"Yes, I'm mama!"

milestone: Begins to use a spoon (very messily)
activities: Give them their own baby-safe spoon at mealtimes while you feed them with another.
Offer thick foods like yogurt or oatmeal.

milestone: Takes first independent steps (can range widely)
activities: Celebrate every attempt!
Sit on the floor a few feet away and encourage them to walk to you.
Avoid hard-soled shoes indoors to let them feel the floor.

milestone: Points with index finger to ask for or indicate something
activities: When they point, name the object for them.
"You're pointing at the dog!" This builds vocabulary and shows you understand them.

milestone: Can name one or two familiar objects when asked (e.g., "Where's the ball?")
activities: Read picture books and ask them to point to familiar objects.
"Can you find the apple?"

milestone: Has a vocabulary of 1-3 words besides "mama" and "dada"
activities: Narrate your day and emphasize key words.
If they try to say "ball," even if it sounds like "ba," confirm and praise: "Yes, ball!"

milestone: Can stack two blocks
activities: Use large, lightweight blocks.
Show them how to place one on top of the other, then let them try.

milestone: Stoops to pick something up and stands back up without falling
activities: Leave interesting (but safe) toys on the floor to encourage this movement.
This shows great progress in balance and coordination.

milestone: Imitates household chores like wiping a surface or talking on a phone
activities: Give them a toy phone or a soft cloth.
They love to copy the activities they see you doing every day.

milestone: Makes scribbles with a large crayon
activities: Tape a large piece of paper to the floor or a high chair tray.
Provide one or two large, non-toxic crayons and let them explore.

milestone: Points to one or two body parts on command (e.g., "Where is your nose?")
activities: Sing "Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes."
Make it a game during bath time or diaper changes.

milestone: Helps with dressing by pushing an arm through a sleeve or a foot into a shoe
activities: Talk them through the process of getting dressed.
"Okay, now let's put your arm through the sleeve. Push!"

milestone: Walks independently and confidently
activities: Go for walks outside on different surfaces like grass and gentle slopes.
Play games that involve walking, like "Red Light, Green Light" (simplified).

milestone: Shows affection with hugs and kisses
activities: Model affectionate behavior.
When they give you a hug, respond warmly: "Thank you for that lovely hug!"

milestone: Has a vocabulary of 3-5 words (besides "mama/dada")
activities: When they say a word, expand on it.
If they say "dog," you say "Yes, a big, fluffy dog!" This models longer sentences.

milestone: Climbs onto low furniture, like a small chair or the sofa
activities: Ensure furniture is stable and create a safe climbing space with floor cushions.
Supervise closely.
Teach them how to get down feet-first.

milestone: Follows a one-step command that involves a familiar object (e.g., "Bring me your cup")
activities: Practice simple commands during daily routines.
Make it a fun game, not a test.
Use clear, simple language.

milestone: Can stack 2-3 blocks
activities: Use large, lightweight wooden or plastic blocks.
Demonstrate how to stack them, then celebrate when they knock them down and when they build their own.

milestone: Begins to identify one or two body parts on themselves
activities: Play "Where is your nose?" and gently touch it.
Use a mirror to point out their eyes, nose, and mouth together.

milestone: Turns the pages of a board book (often several at a time)
activities: Let them "help" you turn the pages as you read.
Board books are durable and perfect for this stage.

milestone: Pushes and pulls toys while walking
activities: Provide push toys like a small lawnmower or a toy stroller.
These build coordination and confidence in walking.

milestone: Throws a ball underhand
activities: Use a soft, lightweight ball.
Sit on the floor and practice rolling and tossing it back and forth.

milestone: Hands a toy or book to a caregiver to initiate play
activities: Show enthusiasm! "You brought me the car! Vroom vroom!"
This reinforces that they can lead the interaction and that you are an engaged play partner.

milestone: Removes simple articles of clothing (e.g., socks, hat, mittens)
activities: Make it a game when you get home.
"Can you pull off your hat?" Praise their independence.

milestone: Walks up stairs while holding on to a rail or hand
activities: Practice together, letting them lead while you stay close behind for safety.
Count the steps as you go.

milestone: Engages in simple pretend play (e.g., "feeds" a doll or talks on a toy phone)
activities: Provide simple props like toy food, a doll, or a toy phone.
Model the actions first: "Mmm, this pretend banana is yummy."

milestone: Vocabulary expands to 10-20 words
activities: Continue to narrate your day and read books daily.
Point to objects and name them clearly.

milestone: Points to the correct picture in a book when named ("Where is the cat?")
activities: Read books with clear, simple pictures of familiar objects.
Make it a fun pointing game.

milestone: Runs (may be stiff and uncoordinated)
activities: Play chase in a safe, open area like a park.
This is a great way to build coordination and burn off energy.

milestone: Can build a tower of 4 blocks
activities: Continue playing with blocks.
Show them how to make the tower taller.
This builds concentration and hand-eye coordination.

milestone: Shakes head to indicate "no"
activities: Acknowledge their communication.
If they shake their head when offered peas, say "Okay, no peas for you." This validates their growing autonomy.

milestone: Attempts to use a spoon and fork correctly (still messy)
activities: Provide child-safe utensils at every meal.
Pre-load the spoon or fork for them to practice bringing it to their mouth.

milestone: Kicks a ball forward
activities: Use a large, lightweight ball.
Show them how to kick it, then cheer for their attempts.

milestone: Begins to show frustration and may have tantrums when unable to communicate or do something
activities: This is a normal part of development. Stay calm.
Acknowledge their feelings ("You're so frustrated the blocks fell!") and offer comfort or a distraction.

milestone: Understands the concept of "mine"
activities: This is a normal cognitive step towards understanding ownership.
Gently model sharing: "It's my turn with the block, then it's your turn."

milestone: Names 3-5 familiar objects when they see them
activities: When they point and name something, affirm them.
"Yes, that is a car!" Play "What's that?" with objects around the house.

milestone: Completes a simple knob puzzle (3-5 pieces)
activities: Start with puzzles where each piece is a distinct shape (e.g., circle, square, triangle).
Guide their hand to show how the pieces fit.

milestone: Follows a two-step related command (e.g., "Pick up your teddy bear and bring it to me")
activities: Start with simple, logical sequences.
"Let's get your shoes and put them on." Use this during everyday routines.

milestone: Plays alongside another child, but not yet with them (parallel play)
activities: Arrange short playdates.
Provide plenty of toys to minimize squabbles.
Don't force interaction; just being near another child is a key social step.

milestone: Vocabulary explodes to 50+ words
activities: Sing songs, read rhyming books, and talk constantly.
The more language they hear, the more they will learn and use.

milestone: Throws a ball overhand
activities: Practice with beanbags or soft balls.
Aim for a large laundry basket to make it a fun game.

milestone: Begins to combine two words into a simple phrase ("More juice," "Bye-bye car," "All gone")
activities: This is a huge milestone! Expand their phrases.
If they say "More juice," you say "You want more apple juice?"

milestone: Attempts to wash and dry hands
activities: Use a step stool so they can reach the sink.
Make it a fun part of the routine before meals and after playing outside.

milestone: Can identify 5-6 body parts on themselves or a doll
activities: Continue singing "Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes."
Ask them to point to your nose, or their doll's tummy.

milestone: Unscrews a lid on a jar or bottle
activities: Provide a large, empty plastic jar with a lid that is easy to turn.
This builds hand strength and problem-solving skills.

milestone: Runs well without falling often
activities: Play tag and follow-the-leader.
Create simple obstacle courses with pillows to run around and cushions to jump over.

milestone: Begins to combine two words into phrases ("More milk," "My ball")
activities: This is a huge milestone! Expand their phrases.
If they say "More milk," you say "You want more milk in your cup?"

milestone: Can build a tower of 6 or more blocks
activities: Use blocks of different shapes and sizes.
Challenge them to see how high they can build it before it tumbles.

milestone: Removes most of their own simple clothing (pants, loose shirt)
activities: Encourage them to "help" get undressed before bath time.
Choose loose-fitting clothing to make it easier and build their confidence.

milestone: Follows two-step, unrelated commands (e.g., "Pick up the book and put it on the table")
activities: Use this during cleanup time.
"Please get your bear and put it in the toy box." Break it down if they struggle, and praise each step.

milestone: Imitates drawing a vertical line
activities: On a large piece of paper, draw a straight line down and say "vrooom!" like a car.
Give them the crayon and see if they copy the motion.

milestone: Vocabulary includes 50+ words (verbs, nouns, adjectives)
activities: Read books with rich language.
When you see a dog, don't just say "dog," say "Look at that big, brown, fluffy dog running fast!"

milestone: Shows increasing independence and defiance ("Mine!", "No!")
activities: This is normal! Offer limited, acceptable choices: "Do you want to wear the red shirt or the blue shirt?"
This gives them a sense of control.

milestone: Jumps with both feet off the floor
activities: Practice being a frog or a bunny.
Put a piece of tape on the floor and encourage them to jump over the "puddle."

milestone: Begins to sort objects by a single attribute (e.g., all the red blocks together)
activities: Use colored bowls and have them sort pom-poms or blocks by color.
"Let's put all the blue ones in the blue bowl."

milestone: Kicks a large ball with some accuracy
activities: Set up a "goal" (between two pillows) and practice kicking a ball into the net.

milestone: Can say their first name when asked
activities: Sing songs that include their name.
Ask "Who is this?" while looking in a mirror.

milestone: Walks up and down stairs independently (may still place both feet on each step)
activities: Continue to supervise on stairs, but let them practice without holding your hand if they are ready.
They might hold the wall or rail.

milestone: Uses pronouns like "me," "my," and "you" (may not always be correct)
activities: Model correct pronoun use.
If they say "Me want cookie," you can respond, "Oh, *you* want a cookie? *I* can get one for you."

milestone: Pretend play becomes more complex (acts out multi-step scenarios like cooking a meal, putting a doll to bed)
activities: Provide props for a play kitchen or a doll's bedroom.
Follow their lead in the play, asking questions like "Is the baby sleepy now?"

milestone: Imitates drawing a horizontal line and a circle
activities: Draw a circle and call it a "ball" or the "sun."
Draw a line across the page and call it a "road" for a toy car.

milestone: Understands simple opposites (big/little, up/down, hot/cold)
activities: Talk about opposites in daily life.
"This is a *big* truck, and that's a *little* car." "Let's stand *up*! Now let's sit *down*."

milestone: Stringing large beads or macaroni onto a shoelace
activities: Use large wooden beads with a thick shoelace (with a knot at one end).
This is excellent for hand-eye coordination and concentration.

milestone: Asks simple "what" and "where" questions
activities: Answer their questions patiently and encourage their curiosity.
Ask them questions back: "I see the cat. *Where* is the cat?"

milestone: Can put on a simple piece of clothing, like a hat or loose pants
activities: Lay their pants on the floor and show them how to sit down and put their feet in the leg holes before pulling them up.

milestone: Enjoys looking at books independently and can name many pictures
activities: Keep a basket of board books at their level.
You'll often find them "reading" to themselves, which is a wonderful pre-literacy skill.

milestone: Uses 3-word sentences ("I want more juice," "Daddy go bye-bye")
activities: Continue expanding on their sentences.
"Yes, Daddy did go bye-bye. He went to work."

milestone: Shows interest in other children's play and may join in briefly
activities: At the park, narrate what other kids are doing.
"Look, she is going down the slide. Do you want to try?" Don't force interaction, but facilitate it.

milestone: Can turn a single page in a book
activities: Read paper-page books together (with supervision).
Show them how to gently grasp and turn just one page.

milestone: Completes simple puzzles with 3-5 pieces
activities: Move on from simple knob puzzles to interlocking jigsaw-style puzzles with large pieces.
Work on it together.

milestone: Shows a wide range of emotions (jealousy, affection, excitement, fear)
activities: Name their feelings for them.
"It looks like you feel sad that your turn is over." This builds emotional intelligence.

milestone: Can say about 100-200 words
activities: Your child's vocabulary is growing daily.
Keep talking, singing, and reading to expose them to new words constantly.

milestone: Begins to show signs of readiness for potty training (e.g., stays dry longer, is interested in the toilet, tells you they have to go)
activities: This varies widely. If they show interest, get a potty chair and let them explore it.
Read books about using the potty.
Keep it low-pressure.

milestone: Can build a tower of 8 or more blocks
activities: Challenge them to build a "garage" for their toy cars or a "castle" for their animal figures.

milestone: Understands the concept of "one" and "all"
activities: During snack time, say "Here is *one* cracker for you. Now you have eaten them *all*!"

milestone: Can follow the plot of a simple story and may be able to answer a question about it ("What did the bear eat?")
activities: Read favorite stories over and over.
They will begin to anticipate what comes next and remember key details.

milestone: Walks up stairs alternating feet (one foot per step)
activities: Make it a game by counting the stairs as you go up.
Hold the rail for safety, but encourage them not to rely on your hand.

milestone: Can name a friend
activities: Talk about their friends from daycare or the park by name.
"I wonder what Leo is doing today?" This helps them build a concept of friendship.

milestone: Jumps forward a short distance
activities: Lay a rope on the ground and pretend it's a "river" they have to jump over.

milestone: Begins to use a fork effectively
activities: Provide a child-safe fork with thicker tines.
Spear soft, bite-sized foods like cooked carrots or melon to make it easier.

milestone: Can match identical objects or pictures
activities: Play a simple memory game with 3-4 pairs of cards face up, asking them to find the two that are the same.

milestone: Constantly asks "Why?"
activities: This is a huge cognitive leap! Answer simply and, when possible, turn it back to them: "That's a good question. Why do *you* think the sky is blue?"

milestone: Sorts objects into two groups (e.g., by color and then by shape)
activities: Use blocks and say, "Let's find all the red ones. Now, out of the red ones, let's find all the circles."

milestone: Can open a door by turning the knob
activities: This is a big step for independence and safety.
Ensure safety locks are in place on doors leading to unsafe areas.

milestone: Uses plural words correctly (e.g., "cats," "dogs," "balls")
activities: When you see more than one of something, model the language.
"Look! I see two *dogs*!"

milestone: Snips paper with child-safe scissors (requires supervision)
activities: Draw thick lines on a piece of paper and hold it taut for them while they practice making small snips.

milestone: Dresses self in simple, loose-fitting clothes (e.g., pulling on pants and a t-shirt)
activities: Lay clothes out for them.
Choose items without tricky buttons or zippers to build confidence.

milestone: Can say their full name (first and last)
activities: Practice their full name in a song.
Create a "sign-in" sheet where they can watch you write their name.

milestone: Stands on one foot for 1-2 seconds
activities: Play "flamingo" and see who can stand on one leg the longest.
Hold their hand for balance at first.

milestone: Names at least one color correctly
activities: Focus on one primary color a week.
Go on a "color hunt" around the house to find everything that is red.

milestone: Shows empathy and concern for others (e.g., pats a crying friend)
activities: When you see this, praise it.
"That was so kind of you to check on your friend." Read books that discuss feelings.

milestone: Speaks in 4-5 word sentences
activities: Have "conversations" where you listen and respond to their stories.
Ask open-ended questions that require a longer answer.

milestone: Can do a simple interlocking puzzle of 4-6 pieces
activities: Work on puzzles together.
Talk about the picture that you are building.

milestone: Begins to understand the concept of time (e.g., "yesterday," "in the morning")
activities: Use a visual schedule with pictures to help them understand the sequence of the day.
Talk about what you will do "after lunch."

milestone: Pedals a tricycle
activities: Start with a balance bike or scooter to teach balance.
Ensure the seat is the right height so their feet can easily push the pedals.

milestone: Takes turns in a game with some reminders
activities: Play simple board games or a game of stacking blocks.
Use a timer or say "My turn, then your turn" to structure the turn-taking.

milestone: Tells a simple story or recounts a recent event
activities: Ask them about their day.
"What was the most fun thing you did at the park?" Help them by prompting: "And then what happened?"

milestone: Can say their age, holding up the correct number of fingers
activities: Practice counting their fingers.
Talk about their upcoming birthday to reinforce the concept of turning a year older.

milestone: Draws a person with a head and one or two other features ("tadpole" person)
activities: Don't correct their drawings.
Ask them about their picture: "Tell me about this person you drew!" Provide lots of paper and crayons.

milestone: Understands prepositions like "in," "on," and "under"
activities: Play a game where you hide a toy and give them clues.
"Look *under* the pillow." "Is it *in* the box?"

milestone: Sings a familiar song from memory
activities: Sing songs like "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" or the "Alphabet Song" together.
They will start to sing it on their own during play.

milestone: Catches a large bounced ball with arms and body
activities: Use a large, lightweight playground ball.
Bounce it gently so they have time to react and trap it against their body.

milestone: Interacts with other children in associative play (playing the same game, but not yet fully cooperating)
activities: At the sandbox, they might all be digging, sharing tools, and talking, but without a common goal.
This is a bridge to cooperative play.

milestone: Recognizes the first letter of their own name
activities: Use magnetic letters on the fridge.
Point out the first letter of their name everywhere you see it (on signs, in books).

milestone: Speech is understandable to strangers most of the time
activities: Encourage them to order their own drink at a cafe or tell a relative about their new toy over the phone to build confidence.

milestone: Can tell you what to do with common objects ("What do you do with a cup?")
activities: Ask them functional questions during play.
"What do we use a spoon for?" "What do you wear on your feet when it's cold?"

milestone: Follows rules in a simple game
activities: Play games like "Simon Says" or "Red Light, Green Light."
Keep it fun and lighthearted, focusing on participation over perfection.

milestone: Pedals a tricycle confidently
activities: Go for "family bike rides" in a safe area.
Set up a simple "race track" with chalk on a driveway.

milestone: Can say their age and gender
activities: Practice this as part of their introduction.
"Hi, I'm Sarah. I'm three and I'm a girl!"

milestone: Unbuttons large buttons
activities: Provide a "dressing frame" or a doll with large-buttoned clothes.
Start with them unbuttoning a coat you've already started.

milestone: Follows a 3-step command (e.g., "Get your shoes, put them on, and wait by the door")
activities: Make this a part of daily routines.
Use a calm, clear voice and break it down if needed.
Praise them for remembering all the steps.

milestone: Asks "Who?", "What?", "Where?", and "Why?" questions frequently
activities: Encourage their curiosity. Answer their questions simply.
Ask them questions back: "Who do you think lives in that house?"

milestone: Can build a tower of 9 or more blocks
activities: Introduce more complex building challenges, like creating a "bridge" by placing a long block between two towers.

milestone: Engages in cooperative play with another child for a short time (working toward a common goal)
activities: Provide a shared project, like building a large block tower together, working on a floor puzzle, or playing "house."

milestone: Can name most familiar things and pictures
activities: Play "I Spy" with more descriptive clues.
"I spy something red that you eat."

milestone: Can tell you their first and last name
activities: Practice singing a song with their full name.
Let them see their name written down.

milestone: Speech is clear enough for strangers to understand most of the time
activities: Encourage them to order their own snack at a counter or tell a story to a grandparent on the phone.

milestone: Draws a person with a head and at least two other body parts (e.g., eyes, mouth)
activities: Ask them to "draw our family."
Talk about the different parts of the body as they draw.

milestone: Understands the concept of "two"
activities: Count everything. "You have *two* eyes."
"Let's get *two* books to read." Hold up two fingers as you say the number.

milestone: Hops on one foot a few times
activities: Play hopscotch with large chalk squares.
Pretend to be bunnies hopping through a garden.

milestone: Sings a song or says a nursery rhyme from memory
activities: Sing favorite songs often.
Pause before the last word of a line and let them fill in the blank.

milestone: Puts on their own coat or jacket
activities: Teach them the "flip trick": lay the coat on the floor upside down, have them stand at the top, put their arms in, and flip it over their head.

milestone: Uses scissors to cut along a thick, straight line
activities: Draw a "road" on a piece of construction paper for them to cut along.
Always supervise scissor use.

milestone: Tells longer stories, which may be a mix of real events and imagination
activities: Write down their stories for them and read them back.
This shows them their words are important and introduces the concept of writing.

milestone: Can name 3-4 colors correctly
activities: Play sorting games with colored bears or blocks.
"Can you find all the yellow ones?"

milestone: Serves self simple food (e.g., pours cereal into a bowl, gets water from a small pitcher)
activities: Start with small amounts of dry cereal or water in a tiny pitcher to minimize spills.
Praise their effort and independence.

milestone: Shows awareness of past and future (e.g., "We went to the park yesterday," "We will see Grandma tomorrow")
activities: Use a simple calendar to mark special events.
Talk about the plan for the day each morning.

milestone: Can complete a 10-12 piece puzzle
activities: Choose puzzles with a clear picture and distinct shapes.
Work on it together as a team.

milestone: Draws a square
activities: Practice drawing "windows" on a picture of a house.
Use your finger to trace a square shape on their back.

milestone: Balances on one foot for 3-5 seconds
activities: Play "statue" or see who can stand like a flamingo the longest.

milestone: Understands and follows rules in simple group games like "Duck, Duck, Goose"
activities: Play these games as a family first to teach the rules in a low-pressure environment.

milestone: Correctly uses "he" and "she"
activities: When reading books, point out the characters.
"Look, *he* is running. *She* is climbing a tree."

milestone: Can count 5-10 objects with one-to-one correspondence (touches each object as they say the number)
activities: Count snacks as you put them on their plate.
Count the steps as you walk up to the house.

milestone: Relates to and plays with an imaginary friend
activities: This is a normal and healthy sign of a strong imagination.
Show interest and play along when invited.

milestone: Can say what they did during their day in sequence
activities: Ask specific questions: "What did you do after you had your snack?"
"Who did you play with outside?"

milestone: Negotiates solutions to conflicts (e.g., "I'll have it for two minutes, then you can")
activities: When conflicts arise with a friend, act as a "coach" instead of a "referee."
Help them voice their feelings and brainstorm solutions.

milestone: Recognizes several letters, especially those in their own name
activities: Use alphabet puzzles and magnetic letters.
Point out the letters of their name on signs and in books.

milestone: Catches a bounced ball with their hands (not trapping against their body)
activities: Stand close and gently bounce a large, lightweight ball to them.
As they improve, you can stand farther away.
